channel.title: Comments on: Museums as the Cathedrals or Mausoleums of Post-Modernity?

item.title: By: J.R.
item.dc:creator: J.R.
item.description: Peaty, I noticed that your division between the Church and the Modern Museum parallels, and not incidentally, the division I spoke about in my essay /j-r/on-the-use-and-abuse-of-cleavage/</a>, that between a religious and secular ritualism or ideology. I did briefly mention Deleuze's theory of the baroque church as a 'field' that pulls the visitor (viewer) into a 2nd plane, a transcendent one, which I think is what you emphasize with your question about the "ivory tower" and "aesthetic transcendence". It is interesting though, since I transitioned in my essay from the church to cleavage, to remain glued to the standpoint of architecture as it continues to offer a sacred experience in its modern (postmodern? -- I know one babyvitruvius who says architecture can never become postmodern) form. Though of course I think you were being quite nice, or nicer than I would be about these places. And you weren't even being that nice ;)
